eventDescription: A rally began at Hambach Castle where participants demonstrated for the liberalization and unification of the German states.
German revolutions of 1848–49: An assembly in Mannheim adopted a resolution demanding a bill of rights.

German Revolution of 1918–19: The Council of the People's Deputies, a body elected from the workers' councils of Berlin, introduced sweeping liberal reforms including the elimination of the Prussian three-class franchise and women's suffrage.

The German Emergency Acts were passed, amending the Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany to allow for the restriction of certain freedoms in the event of an emergency, and marking a major political defeat for the German student movement.

Uprising of 1953 in East Germany: In response to a 10 percent increase in work quotas, between 60 and 80 construction workers went on strike in East Berlin. Their numbers quickly swelled and a general strike and protests were called for the next day.
Monday demonstrations in East Germany: A peaceful demonstration began in Leipzig, in East Germany, which called for democracy and the right of citizens to travel abroad.

eventTitle: Treaty on the final settelment with respect to Germany
eventDescription: The Treaty on the Final Settlement with Respect to Germany was signed by East and West Germany, the United States, the United Kingdom, France and the Soviet Union. The latter four renounced all rights they held in Germany.
The Freikorps Marinebrigade Ehrhardt occupied Berlin. Wolfgang Kapp of the national conservative German National People's Party (DNVP) declared himself chancellor.

Beer Hall Putsch: Nazi Party chairman Adolf Hitler led some six hundred Sturmabteilung (SA) to the Bürgerbräukeller in Munich, where they held Bavarian state officials Gustav Ritter von Kahr, Hans Ritter von Seisser and Otto von Lossow at gunpoint to demand they support a Nazi coup.

After the unification of Germany under Emperor Wilhelm I in 1871, elections were held to the German Reichstag or "Imperial Assembly", which supplanted its namesake, the Reichstag of the Norddeutscher Bund.
With the Weimar Republic's Constitution of 1919, the voting system changed from single-member constituencies to proportional representation. The election age was reduced from 25 to 20 years of age.
West German federal election, 1949: The CDU and Christian Social Union in Bavaria (CSU) won a narrow plurality of seats in the Bundestag.
Description -needed
The General German Workers' Association was formed on 23rd May.
Description -needed
The Pan-German League was a Pan-German nationalist organization which officially founded in 1891
Night of the Long Knives: SS paramilitaries killed at least eighty-five potential threats to Hitler's power, including SA head Ernst Röhm and Gregor Strasser, head of the left wing of the Nazi Party.
The process of Gleichschaltung, in which the government dismantled non-Nazi parties and societies, began.
Hitler issued a law merging the powers of the presidency into the office of the chancellor.
Wannsee Conference: A government conference was held to discuss the implementation of the Final Solution, the extermination of European Jewry.

Potsdam Conference: British prime minister Clement Attlee, president Harry S. Truman of the United States and Joseph Stalin, the general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, issued the Potsdam Agreement at Cecilienhof in Potsdam. The parties agreed that Germany would be returned to its 1937 borders with some additional cessions to the Soviet Union and ratified its division into British, French, American and Soviet occupation zones.
East and West Germany signed the Basic Treaty, in which each recognized the other's sovereignty.
German reunification: Five East German states acceded to West Germany. Berlin became the capital of Germany.
The Maastricht Treaty establishing the European Union (EU) was signed by twelve European countries including Germany.
The checkpoints on the Berlin Wall were opened.
Occupation of the Ruhr: France invaded the valley of the Ruhr.
Construction began on the Berlin Wall between East and West Berlin.

The Constitution of the German Reich (German: Die Verfassung des Deutschen Reichs), usually known as the Weimar Constitution (Weimarer Verfassung) was the constitution that governed Germany during the Weimar Republic era

70 years of Basic Law are therefore a good reason to celebrate this milestone in German history, the celebration of the constitution on May 22 focuses on the bright and dark sides of the German legal system
East Germany, officially the German Democratic Republic, was a country that existed from 1949 to 1990, when the eastern portion of Germany was part of the Eastern Bloc during the Cold War.

West Germany was the informal name for the Federal Republic of Germany from 1949 to 1990, a period referred to by historians as the Bonn Republic, an era when the western portion of Germany was part of the Western bloc during the Cold War.
